step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Market Awareness of AI Tools
step1_initial_points.description: The government lacks a clear understanding of the current AI tools and services available that are relevant to its functions. This RFI aims to gain market intelligence to inform a future "catalogue of offerings" and guide strategic procurement planning.

step1_initial_points.title: Ensuring AI Security and Data Privacy
step1_initial_points.description: Protecting sensitive government data is paramount. Any AI solution must comply with strict government policies like the South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) and demonstrate robust measures to safeguard data, a critical hurdle for adopting new technologies.

step1_initial_points.title: Compliance with Government ICT Policies
step1_initial_points.description: AI tools must fit within a complex existing regulatory framework. Solutions need to adhere to all "Applicable ICT, Security and Cyber policies," creating a high barrier to entry and requiring vendors to demonstrate deep compliance understanding.

step1_initial_points.title: Integrating AI with Legacy Systems
step1_initial_points.description: The government faces challenges integrating modern AI into its existing IT infrastructure. They need to assess the "adaptability of vendor solutions... for integration into existing government systems" to ensure technical feasibility and avoid costly failures.

step1_initial_points.title: Unpredictable AI Costs and Budgeting
step1_initial_points.description: The government cannot effectively plan or allocate budgets for AI without clear cost information. They are seeking "indicative costing models and pricing structures" to understand the total cost of ownership and make informed financial decisions for future projects.

step1_initial_points.title: Pressure to Improve Public Service Delivery
step1_initial_points.description: There is a strategic imperative to leverage technology for better citizen outcomes. DPC is exploring AI to "improve service delivery, increase public satisfaction, and achieve better community outcomes," making this a key performance driver for any new solution.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Proven Government Use Cases
step1_initial_points.description: Being risk-averse, the government seeks validation before adoption. They need to "learn from vendors' experiences in deploying AI solutions within similar... government contexts" to see proven best practices, de-risk investment, and build confidence.

step1_initial_points.title: Internal AI Skills Gap
step1_initial_points.description: The current workforce may not be ready for widespread AI adoption. The request for information on "Staff and tool training needed" indicates an awareness of an internal skills gap that must be addressed for successful implementation and management of new AI tools.

step1_initial_points.title: Need for Robust AI Governance and Policy
step1_initial_points.description: The government is in the process of defining its own rules and policies for AI use. This RFI will "inform subsequent... policy development," highlighting their challenge in creating a comprehensive and safe governance framework for emerging AI technologies.

step1_initial_points.title: Uncertainty of Solution Maturity & Scalability
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer is concerned about investing in unproven or limited technology. A key goal is to "Assess the maturity, scalability, and adaptability of vendor solutions" to ensure any chosen tool is reliable, enterprise-ready, and can grow with their needs.

step1_initial_points.title: Managing Third-Party LLM Dependencies
step1_initial_points.description: The reliance on external Large Language Models (LLMs) presents risks. They explicitly ask how solutions integrate with third-party LLMs to understand and manage dependencies related to data security, operational control, and ongoing performance.

step1_initial_points.title: Inefficient AI Procurement Process
step1_initial_points.description: The current procurement approach is likely not agile enough for AI. The objective to create a "catalogue of offerings" suggests a pain point in a slow, case-by-case procurement process, which they want to streamline for future AI projects.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Low-Risk AI Trial Opportunities
step1_initial_points.description: Committing to a large-scale AI deployment is risky without prior testing. The buyer wants to "explore opportunities for... pilot initiatives" to trial solutions in real-world scenarios, allowing them to validate value and feasibility before a major investment.

step1_initial_points.title: Unclear Internal Resource Requirements
step1_initial_points.description: The buyer is unsure of the internal investment needed to support AI. They are asking vendors what "DPC resources and infrastructure will be required for deployment," showing a need to understand the full scope of internal commitments beyond just licensing costs.

step1_initial_points.title: Keeping Pace with Rapid AI Evolution
step1_initial_points.description: The AI landscape changes extremely fast, making long-term strategy difficult. DPC's plan to "conduct regular RFIs... beginning in 2026" signals a strategic challenge in maintaining current knowledge and avoiding technological obsolescence.

step2_filtered_points.description: Protecting sensitive government data is paramount. Any AI solution must comply with strict government policies like the South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) and demonstrate robust measures to safeguard data, a critical hurdle for adopting new technologies.

step2_filtered_points.description: The reliance on external Large Language Models (LLMs) presents risks. They explicitly ask how solutions integrate with third-party LLMs to understand and manage dependencies related to data security, operational control, and ongoing performance.

step2_filtered_points.description: The government faces challenges integrating modern AI into its existing IT infrastructure. They need to assess the "adaptability of vendor solutions... for integration into existing government systems" to ensure technical feasibility and avoid costly failures.

step2_filtered_points.description: The government cannot effectively plan or allocate budgets for AI without clear cost information. They are seeking "indicative costing models and pricing structures" to understand the total cost of ownership and make informed financial decisions for future projects.

step2_filtered_points.title: Lack of Proven Government Use Cases
step2_filtered_points.description: Being risk-averse, the government seeks validation before adoption. They need to "learn from vendors' experiences in deploying AI solutions within similar... government contexts" to see proven best practices, de-risk investment, and build confidence.

step2_filtered_points.title: Internal AI Skills Gap
step2_filtered_points.description: The current workforce may not be ready for widespread AI adoption. The request for information on "Staff and tool training needed" indicates an awareness of an internal skills gap that must be addressed for successful implementation and management of new AI tools.

step2_filtered_points.title: Uncertainty of Solution Maturity & Scalability
step2_filtered_points.description: The buyer is concerned about investing in unproven or limited technology. A key goal is to "Assess the maturity, scalability, and adaptability of vendor solutions" to ensure any chosen tool is reliable, enterprise-ready, and can grow with their needs.

step2_filtered_points.title: Lack of Low-Risk AI Trial Opportunities
step2_filtered_points.description: Committing to a large-scale AI deployment is risky without prior testing. The buyer wants to "explore opportunities for... pilot initiatives" to trial solutions in real-world scenarios, allowing them to validate value and feasibility before a major investment.

step2_filtered_points.title: Keeping Pace with Rapid AI Evolution
step2_filtered_points.description: The AI landscape changes extremely fast, making long-term strategy difficult. DPC's plan to "conduct regular RFIs... beginning in 2026" signals a strategic challenge in maintaining current knowledge and avoiding technological obsolescence.

step3_refined_points.title: Navigating AI Governance & Security Mandates
step3_refined_points.description: The government must ensure any AI solution meets stringent security, data privacy (IPPs), and ICT policies. This includes managing risks from third-party LLMs, creating a high barrier for vendors who must demonstrate robust compliance to protect sensitive government data.

step3_refined_points.title: De-risking Investment in Unproven AI Technology
step3_refined_points.description: Being risk-averse, the government lacks confidence in the maturity and scalability of new AI tools. They need vendors to provide proven government use cases, demonstrate market leadership, and offer low-risk pilot opportunities to validate value before committing to a major investment.

step3_refined_points.title: Overcoming AI Budget & Integration Hurdles
step3_refined_points.description: The government faces major practical barriers to adoption. They cannot plan or allocate budgets without clear, predictable cost models and must ensure any new AI tool can be feasibly integrated with their existing legacy IT infrastructure to avoid costly technical failures.

step3_refined_points.title: Closing the Internal AI Skills & Readiness Gap
step3_refined_points.description: Successful AI adoption is threatened by a lack of internal expertise. The government recognizes a critical skills gap and needs a clear plan for staff training to ensure their workforce can effectively implement, manage, and utilize new AI technologies across the organization.

merge_decisions.merged: De-risking Investment in Unproven AI Technology

pain_points_final.title: Navigating AI Governance & Security Mandates
pain_points_final.description: The government must ensure any AI solution meets stringent security, data privacy (IPPs), and ICT policies. This includes managing risks from third-party LLMs, creating a high barrier for vendors who must demonstrate robust compliance to protect sensitive government data.

pain_points_final.title: Closing the Internal AI Skills & Readiness Gap
pain_points_final.description: Successful AI adoption is threatened by a lack of internal expertise. The government recognizes a critical skills gap and needs a clear plan for staff training to ensure their workforce can effectively implement, manage, and utilize new AI technologies across the organization.
